message_1:
A math student needs to determine the truth value of the following compound proposition:

(p ∧ q) ∨ ¬p 

where p is true and q is false. Is the entire proposition true or false?
message_2:
To determine the truth value of the compound proposition, we will evaluate each part of the proposition using the given values of p and q.

Given: p is true and q is false.

1. (p ∧ q): This is a conjunction, which means it is true if and only if both p and q are true. Since p is true and q is false, (p ∧ q) is false.

2. ¬p: This is the negation of p. Since p is true, ¬p is false.

Now, we have the compound proposition:

(false) ∨ (false)

3. (p ∧ q) ∨ ¬p: This is a disjunction, which means it is true if at least one of the propositions is true. Since both (p ∧ q) and ¬p are false, the entire proposition (p ∧ q) ∨ ¬p is false.
